snippet: The New York police have come under scrutiny over racial disparities in their stop-and-frisk practice. But the frequency of officers’ use of force in those encounters is often overlooked.
abstract: New York City Police Dept has been under scrutiny over numbers and racial disparities in its 'stop, question and frisk' policy, but what is often overlooked is how often officers use force in these encounters; many who have been stopped say any resistance can result in being slammed against walls, the ground or even having a gun pointed at their heads; maps show concentration of stops, and stops with force, across city.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Daniel Krieger, Randy Leonard, Sarah Maslin Nir, Nate Schweber and Tom Torok.

lead_paragraph: The New York police have come under scrutiny over racial disparities in their stop-and-frisk practice. But the frequency of officers’ use of force in those encounters is often overlooked.

headline.seo: In Police-Stop Data, Pockets Where Force Is Used More Often
headline.main: Pockets of City See Higher Use of Force During Police Stops
headline.print_headline: Police-Stop Data Shows Pockets Where Force Is Used More Often
